title: White middle school student spat on a black person inside the African American History Museum
text:
A white middle school student from Connecticut spat on a black visitor during a class trip to the National Museum of African American History and Culture on Friday - however the school’s principal insists the offensive act wasn’t motivated by race.

The unnamed boy from Shelton Intermediate School spat off a balcony and struck the person below, according to Principal Dina Marks, who was accompanying the students on the trip.

All 100 seventh and eighth graders, along with their 12 chaperones, were kicked out of the Washington DC museum immediately afterwards.

‘It was an act of stupidity, disinterest, & immaturity, completely inappropriate,’ Marks tweeted Saturday, ‘but I believe, not racially motivated against that person.’

She later provided an update on her since-deleted Twitter account saying that the students had returned to their hotel rooms after an ‘unfortunate incident’.

‘Our kids are not bad people,’ the principle ensured. ‘We are all pretty sad tonight’.

Shelton Public Schools Superintendent Chris Clouet said the culprit responsible ‘acted inappropriately and embarrassed himself’, adding that, unlike Marks, he wasn’t sure if the act was racially motivated or not.

‘Far too often unkind acts in our world are excused because it was “only a joke,”’ he told the Hartford Courant. ‘The individual who was spit on may not see it as a joke. I suspect it may have been more rude than racist. Not certain how the visitor to the museum on the receiving end of the act would perceive it.’

The boy was sent home early from the trip, which was meant to last from Wednesday to Sunday, and will face unspecified ‘school-based discipline’, Clouet said.

‘This kind of action is not a reflection of who our students are, or who we are as a community,’ the superintendent continued. ‘This is not the time or place to talk about consequences.’

‘It was an act of stupidity, disinterest, & immaturity, completely inappropriate,’ Principal Dina Marks (left) tweeted Saturday, ‘but I believe, not racially motivated against that person’. Shelton Public Schools Superintendent Chris Clouet (right) said the culprit responsible ‘acted inappropriately and embarrassed himself’, adding that, unlike Marks, he wasn’t sure if the act was racially motivated or not.

The annual event also includes visits to the United State Holocaust Memorial Museum and Arlington National Cemetery.

In a letter to parents, Clouet urged them to speak to their children ‘in an age-appropriate manner about our expectation of how we treat people: Black or White, elder or young, or anyone, a child (or adult!) may perceive as being different.’

Contrary to Marks’ claims, Greg Johnson, president of the Ansonia Valley NAACP, said the location of the incident is all the evidence needed to discern whether the act was ‘just horseplay’ or something far worse.

‘He didn’t spit on anyone at the Washington Monument or the Lincoln Memorial,’ Johnson told the Courant. ‘A total and complete lack of respect and one of the most degrading acts one can commit against another.’

‘It’s an embarrassment not only to Shelton, but to Connecticut,’ he blasted.

In a letter to parents, Clouet urged them to speak to their children ‘in an age-appropriate manner about our expectation of how we treat people: Black or White, elder or young, or anyone, a child (or adult!) may perceive as being different’ (pictured: A statue depicting USA track and field athletes Tommie Smith, C, and John Carlos, R, as they raised gloved fists during their medal ceremony at the 1968 Summer Olympics)

Johnson highlighted that this is the third incident of its kind involving a Shelton youngster in the past few weeks.

Last month the school district investigated a video circulating on Snapchat which showered a female student in blackface making racially offensive gestures and remarks, caption with a racist slur.

The students responsible for the video, who have not been named, were made to apologize during a school assembly that included a slideshow presentation about the racist history of blackface.

Johnson said another youngster at the school was caught using the N-word on social media, but was never reprimanded.

‘There’s no accountability,’ he said. ‘It’s why kids run amok. There’s deeply embedded racism in town.’

Around 35 percent of students in the Shelton Public Schools district are of color, Clout revealed to Buzzfeed.

He said Shelton schools will reach out to students to teach them about increasingly diverse communities.

‘I think my job as an educator is to make sure we're educating our children to live in a multicultural world.’
